author: potuz
content: disks are already fully paralellized for the most, specially while executing.

author: ben_a_adams
content: Not really because we don't know without running the contract what to load from disk; so either serial or at best gapped by lots of cpu running speculative execution to find out what to load (running double the needed cpu if truly parallel)

author: potuz
content: The controller is parallelizing under the hood

author: ben_a_adams
content: Controller can only parallelize requests made/in flight; if can only make the requests serially waiting for result of prior to make next request (executing contract); how can it parallelize?

author: ben_a_adams
content: Are stacking disk latency on top of disk latency with serial requests; parallel requests maximize NVMe bandwidth instead. However need to be able to make them in parallel for that

author: potuz
content: If you're only reading and not storing anything then you'll be reading sequentially, but as soon as you start storing things and passing through the controller's cache, access to actual disk is parallelized. I've tried to look into these metrics cause Prysm was much heavier than other clients IO wise but there's little we can do unless we code at a much lower level

author: ben_a_adams
content: ELs don't really do much disk writing as part of block validation critical path; is all reads (writes happen in batches elsewhere)

author: ben_a_adams
content: Even the major critical part of SSTORE is loading the prior value to work out how much to charge for gas; so a load
